awd_titl_txt: Growing the Regional Computer Science Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "NSF S-STEM Scholarship Program: Computer Science Plus, Plus (CS++)" is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at Middle Tennessee State University. The project is funding 100 scholarships over 5 years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Computer Science. A pipeline of activities will be employed to recruit and retain academically talented students, improve academic performance, inspire exploration of the CS discipline, instill CS career knowledge at an early stage, encourage and provide help to land CS related internships, and hire students with professional experiences as mentors for lower level students.

The CS++ project will study the impact of a proposed new peer-mentoring program, which will leverage the group of CS majors who work in the computing field as mentors for lower level CS majors. Research will focus on the impact of this unique mentoring experience, which seeks to engage younger students in networking and career building activities, primarily through job shadowing and internships, providing real-world insight for the younger students and stronger departmental connections for the working students. Scholarship recipients will be provided a rich set of academic and non-academic services to support their retention in CS. Additionally, the project will focus on two problems identified by local analytics: (1) the low number and percentage of female and other underrepresented minority (URM) CS majors, and (2) the poor retention of lower level students, especially female and other UMR CS majors. The overall success and impact of the CS++ program will be measured based on enrollment and retention in the department.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to provide more computer science graduates, especially underrepresented students (UR) like female and underrepresented minority to middle Tennessee area by recruiting more UR computer science majors and improving their retention rate. To achieve the goal, a pipeline of activities that have been successful at recruiting and retaining UR students were created to recruit and retain academically talented students, improve academic performance, inspire exploration of the computer science discipline, instill CS career knowledge at an early stage, and provide help to land computer science related internships and research. Over the years of the award, our project supported 103 distinctive students directly with 46% of them are female and underrepresented minority students. Our study shows that the project had a very positive effect on our scholars – they tended to stay in the major, complete more courses with higher GPAs per semester and gain working and/or research experience before graduation. As a result, scholars are more likely to graduate sooner and enter the workforce earlier. The project also slightly increased the percentage of female and underrepresented minority students in the department and will provide more female and underrepresented minority students to middle Tennessee area. Overall, the major components of the project like recruitment, professional conference attendance, summer research project and peer mentoring program have proved very successful and had a very positive effect on students and our program. These components can be easily adopted by computer science discipline and other STEM majors.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2024
Modified by: Zhijiang Dong
